title: 115_hr4008
content: The following sums are appropriated for fiscal year 2018 from the Treasury and other revenues for various government departments, agencies, and organizations, including the Federal Emergency Management Agency's disaster relief fund. For major disasters declared under the Stafford Disaster Relief Act, an additional $18.67 billion is allocated to the Disaster Relief Fund, with $10 million designated for audits by the Department of Homeland Security. The Federal Emergency Management Agency must disclose grant awards exceeding $1 million within 5 days on their website. Mission assignments exceeding $1 million to other federal agencies must also be reported within 5 days. The Administrator must publish details of disasters exceeding $1,000,000 within 5 days, including state name, declaration, agency, assistance, description, cost estimate, and amount obligated. Updates on cost estimate and amount obligated must be provided monthly until completion. For hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria, reports must be submitted to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees within 5 days. The Administrator must provide monthly estimates of spending categories for the current fiscal year on the Agency's website. Up to $4,900,000,000 from the Disaster Relief Fund can be transferred for Disaster Assistance. Up to $4,900,000,000 can be transferred to the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account for direct loans to assist local governments affected by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, or Maria. Territories and possessions of the United States are considered local governments for this purpose. The loans cannot exceed $4,900,000,000 in total. Loans to territories, possessions, and local governments for projected revenue loss and cash outlays after a major disaster can exceed $5,000,000 and have specific repayment terms. Loans can be canceled only in whole or in part. Loans issued to territories, possessions, and local governments for projected revenue loss and cash outlays after a major disaster can be canceled in whole or in part at the discretion of the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury. The terms, conditions, eligible uses, and timing of Federal disbursements of loans will be determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury. FEMA may transfer up to 1.5 percent of the amount for administrative expenses related to the direct loan program. The direct loan program, authorized by section 417 of the Stafford Act, allows for up to $150,000,000 to be transferred to the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account for territories or possessions responsible for cost-sharing provisions of major disaster declarations for Hurricanes Irma or Maria. Additionally, up to $1,000,000 may be transferred for administrative expenses related to the Advance of Non-Federal Share program. The amount provided under this heading is designated by Congress for an emergency requirement pursuant to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The Department of Agriculture's Forest Service is allocated an additional $184,500,000 for Wildland Fire Management for urgent fire suppression operations. These funds are to be transferred to other appropriations accounts to fully repay amounts previously transferred in fiscal year 2017. The Congress designates this amount as an emergency requirement. An additional $342,000,000 is allocated for the FLAME Wildfire Suppression Reserve Fund for large wildland fire suppression operations of the Department of Agriculture. The funds are to be used for necessary expenses and as a reserve fund for suppression and Federal emergency response activities. The Congress designates this amount as an emergency requirement. Department-Wide Programs for wildland fire management receive an additional $50,000,000 for urgent fire suppression activities. The funds can be transferred to other accounts for repayment of previous transfers. This amount is designated as an emergency requirement. Sec. 301. Each amount appropriated by this Act is in addition to amounts for the fiscal year. Sec. 302. No part of any appropriation in this Act shall remain available beyond the current fiscal year. Sec. 303. Terms and conditions for funds in this Act also apply to funds in Public Law 115-56. Sec. 304. Amounts designated for emergency requirements are available only if the President designates them. Sec. 305. Deadline for compliance is December 31, 2017. Sec. 305 requires Federal agencies to submit internal control plans for funds by December 31, 2017, and the Government Accountability Office to review the plans by March 31, 2018. All programs receiving funds are considered susceptible to improper payments. Sec. 306 mandates that funds for grants provided by this Act or division B of Public Law 115-56 must be spent by grantees within 24 months, unless a waiver is granted by the Director of OMB with justification submitted to the Committees on Appropriations. Any unspent funds must be returned to the agency. The "Community Development Fund" in division B of Public Law 115-56 is amended to include Indian tribes. Amounts repurposed as emergency requirements are designated accordingly. Section 101(a)(7) of division D of Public Law 115-56 is also amended. Sec. 308 cancels $16 billion of Administrator's outstanding indebtedness under National Flood Insurance Act and Federal Insurance Act. Sec. 308 cancels $16 billion of Administrator's outstanding indebtedness under National Flood Insurance Act and Federal Insurance Act. The canceled amount relieves the Administrator and National Flood Insurance Fund of liability to the Secretary of the Treasury, reducing the total amount of notes and obligations issued. The canceled indebtedness may be treated as public debt of the United States and is designated as an emergency requirement. Sec. 309 allocates $1,270,000,000 for disaster nutrition assistance in Puerto Rico in response to declared disasters and emergencies. The funds are available until September 30, 2019, and are designated as an emergency requirement by Congress. The "Additional Supplemental Appropriations for Disaster Relief Requirements Act of 2017" allows for emergency funding for the Federal Emergency Management Agency in fiscal year 2018, exempting it from certain limitations on advance billing.
